Airbnb is a fast-emerging travel accommodations disrupter valued at $25 billion — but it had a humble beginning. When co-founders Brian Chesky and Joe Gebbia couldn't pay their San Francisco rent, they bought three air mattresses and launched a website to rent each mattress for $80 a night. When they found takers, the proverbial light bulb went off.The company runs a website where traveler "hosts" rent their homes and apartments — or rooms in their homes and apartments — to travelers for short stays of usually a month or less. Airbnb generated Q3 revenue of $340 million on bookings of $2.2 billion, according to a presentation to investors leaked to the Wall Street Journal.The company is losing some $150 million a year, reported the WSJ, but it's also nipping at the heals of online travel agencies (OTAs) such as Expedia (EXPE) and Priceline (PCLN), upending hotel chains such as Hilton (HLT) and Marriott (MAR) and helping establish a regulatory beachhead in the 34,000 cities where it boasts listings, which could also help rivals such as HomeAway (AWAY)."The online travel agencies and (Priceline's) Bookings.com in particular have said they are happy to let Airbnb blaze the (regulatory) trail and bear a lot of those costs," Douglas Quinby, an analyst with online travel research firm Phocuswright, told IBD. "The big OTAs see opportunities, but they would prefer to let Airbnb drive the regulations."Airbnb's staunchly Democratic home city of San Francisco has been a battlefield for crafting regulations for Airbnb and similar businesses. Those regulations include requiring such firms to pay hotel taxes and limiting how long hosts can rent out their homes or apartments.Critics have hammered on the company's strategy of begging for forgivingness vs. asking for permission, meaning they start up operations in a city and only respond to concerns as they surface.But the company notched a big win in a November election, when San Francisco voters resoundingly rejected Proposition F, a restrictive measure that, among other provisions, would force Airbnb to provide a quarterly report saying how many days hosts had listed their properties for rent. Prop F would have limited that 75 days a year, and make violations a misdemeanor.After the dust settled, with Airbnb spending $8 million to defeat the item, the question remains: What does the vote mean for Airbnb and the travel industry?"On the one hand, it's an important win in a key market — the birthplace of Airbnb," Quinby said. "On the other hand, it's kind of meaningless because regulations are all being decided on a local level. And there's no reason to think that because San Francisco does one thing, someone else wouldn't do another."OTAs Say Impact 'Immaterial'On Oct. 29, Expedia CEO Dara Khosrowshaki brushed off Airbnb's impact on his company, speaking on Expedia's earnings conference call. Less than a week later, Expedia announced an agreement to acquire the closest thing Airbnb has to a competitor in public markets: HomeAway. Unlike Airbnb, HomeAway's focus is more tightly centered around renting out entire homes for long vacations. HomeAway, founded in 2005, is valued near $3.48 billion and is expected to end the year with revenue of $500 million. But unlike Airbnb, HomeAway makes money. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate it will end 2015 with an operating profit of $102.5 million.Expedia decline to comment for this story."It's disingenuous to say that (Airbnb is) not having an impact," T. Rowe Price (TROW) portfolio manager Joe Fath told IBD. "I tend to pay attention to what companies do, instead of what they say."Fath manages T. Rowe Price's Growth Stock Fund .The fund bought private stock in Airbnb more than two years ago and has hiked its stake's value some 150% since then. Fath is looking for a "home run" from Airbnb. "Supply is Airbnb's biggest constraint," he said.Analyst Quinby agrees."Without question Airbnb has been a phenomenon in the travel industry over the last several years," he said. "They've created an entirely new category in the travel industry. In 2011, 10% of U.S. travelers stayed in private accommodations. In 2014, that number was up to 25%."For a second straight year, an RBC Capital Markets survey found that one-third of respondents said they have used some form of alternative accommodations, such as Airbnb or HomeAway subsidiary VRBO.One of Fath's largest holdings is Priceline, which he acknowledged hasn't been performing that well in the last 12 months. But he expects the stock will perform better.Also, Priceline is "well hedged" against Airbnb and similar firms because of its growing inventory of alternative lodgings, says RBC analyst Mark Mahaney. In a recent research note, he said Priceline's inventory of 361,000 properties is up 80% over the past year.Hyper-Local Regulations BattleThe regulations fight for short-term rentals is hyper local. The hotels and short-term rentals field isn't regulated federally and there are few state laws, so companies must work with each municipality. But while the impact of the San Francisco vote was geographically limited, it was closely watched because of the precedent it would set.Airbnb "needed to fight this because ... if Proposition F passed, it would have stymied their ability to do business," Ed Zitron, an SF-based tech public relations executive uninvolved in the Prop F election, told IBD. "A defeat would have ... scared investors."The Airbnb win was a loss for the hotel industry, which led the fight to pass the measure. Still, the benefit of Prop F is that a lot of issues got aired "in a public forum," Troy Flanagan, vice president of state and local affairs for the American Hotel and Lodging Association, told IBD. "This is one of the first times, if not the first time, such a comprehensive proposal for online, modern short-term rentals was floated. It was a public, open debate in the hometown of Airbnb."People renting out multiple units are hoteliers, but they aren't being held to the same standards (as hoteliers)."Airbnb, in fact, says it currently collects taxes only in 24 cities in two states, according to a spokesman.When IBD asked Airbnb what the stakes were in the Prop F vote, company spokesman Christopher Nulty wrote in an email that "Proposition F was a hotel-funded campaign attempting to scare San Franciscans into believing this measure would do a single thing to address affordability in San Francisco. We remain committed to working with policymakers across the country and around the globe to develop smart, common sense regulations that allow regular people to share their homes while contributing to their communities."Airbnb declined to make any executive available for this story. But CEO Chesky told Re/Code that losing the S.F. vote would have hurt. "... You can win 10 cities in Europe but you lose your home city and it basically just seems like you're losing ground completely," Re/Code quoted Chesky saying. "We have 130,000 members (hosts and guests) in San Francisco. They ended up winning the ballot, not us. I used to say they're on the ballot, not us. Because we're going to be in 33,999 cities and they're the ones really at stake here, for us it's more of a brand issue."Affordable housing is a huge issue in San Francisco and the greater Bay Area amid skyrocketing rents and home prices, so renting out a room can help a homeowner.HomeAway says its preferred tactic is to train property owners and managers to lobby their city governments, rather than get embroiled in a Prop F-type election."That's our traditional path," Matt Curtis, HomeAway's director of government relations, told IBD. "We don't do campaign donations."Curtis agrees with Airbnb that Prop F was too restrictive, and he says HomeAway wants to ensure "fair and effective" regulations in cities where the company operates."Communities that have chosen to make burdensome restrictions have driven short-term rental activity underground," Curtis said. So, those businesses are "not paying taxes, operating outside the existing framework."

The recent share price action is nothing to write home about, but the fundamentals are striking for real estate investment trust Hersha Hospitality (HT) .The Philadelphia-based REIT owns 53 upscale and mid-scale hotels with 8,508 rooms in big cities such as New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., Miami, Los Angeles and others. Its hotel brands include Hilton (HLT), Marriott (MAR), Hyatt (H), and Starwood's (HOT) Sheraton, and they are geared toward corporate and leisure travelers.The stock attempted to carve out a saucer base, but failed during the summer and remains in a downtrend. The Relative Strength rating is in the low 30s, and the Accumulation/Distribution Rating is a worst possible E, showing that the big investors are sellers.But funds from operation, the REIT equivalent of earnings, along with revenue, have been growing. In the most recent quarter, FFO rose 24% from a year earlier, and revenue rose 10%, with analysts forecasting 15% growth in 2016.Dividend growth has also impressed. After several years of quarterly dividends of 6 cents a share, Hersha raised the payout to 7 cents in 2014, then to 28 cents earlier this year, equal to a 5% annualized dividend yield.Wells Fargo analysts said in November the company is in talks to sell some of its New York and suburban properties. Any proceeds would be used to buy back shares or purchase more hotels.On Dec. 1, Janney Montgomery Scott analysts started coverage at neutral. They said the company is well-run, but they worry about industry factors and the fact the company is highly focused with 71% of earnings coming from New York, Miami and California. There's a danger, they said, of rising supply, poor performance, lagging international travel, loss of pricing power and the proliferation of Airbnb.

Scan the lodging options around most big U.S. airports, and you'll find an abundance of humble accommodations — along with a few best described as frightening. The tony hotels are typically found in city centers, where business travelers, tourists, and conventioneers tend to congregate.

The post-recession U.S. hotel boom is changing that, with upscale airport hotels now planned in Minneapolis-St. Paul, New York City and Atlanta, as well as a 500-room Westin which opened Thursday at Denver International Airport.Given the generally higher costs for a full-service hotel such as a W or Hilton, these projects haven't traditionally mixed with airport traffic that comes and leaves quickly, often because of weather-marred flights. But two travel trends are converging to change that math.Commercial real estate developers are seeing airports as fertile locations, driven by rising demand for rooms and conference space. And U.S. airports are upgrading their facilities to appeal to a more sophisticated clientele, the kind who want such amenities as spas, trendy bistros, and even yoga spaces."Passengers in general have increased their expectations of airports," said Kim Day, chief executive officer of Denver International. "They want higher-end shopping, better food, and they want better places to stay when they stay."That also means a stroll to the hotel lobby from the terminal — no shuttles — along with cutting-edge design, full-service spas, chic bars and upscale restaurants.This new breed of airport hotel also affords ample space for business meetings, given that many companies like the idea of flying employees to a central point near (or in) an airport and getting down to business without the hassles of transit. And with occupancy rates near record levels for most full-service hotels, it's harder for a business group to find room at the inn, which changes the economics of putting a full-service property at or near an airport.Introducing The 'Travel Plaza'Room demand at airport locations has grown from an average of 55 million room nights in 2010 to 65 million today, according to STR, a lodging data and research firm. Average room rates at airport locations have also increased, in line with the overall industry, and now top $110 per night. "The occupancies are so high now some players are saying wait a second, maybe this is a place we should look," said Jan Freitag, an STR senior vice president.The Denver hotel, which has endured a history of fits and starts since the airport's 1995 opening, is designed as a destination for business travelers to meet and a way to bridge the airport with central Denver, which sits nearly 30 miles to the west. In April, a new light rail train will connect the Westin and airport with downtown via a $9 ride that's 37 minutes. Day predicts that line will help make the hotel a destination for weddings and other events.This summer, officials at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International sought bidders for a 300-room, "top-tier" four-star hotel to be built as part of a "travel plaza" that would have office space, a gas station and possibly residential units. Atlanta vies with Chicago's O'Hare as the world's busiest airport hub but has no hotel connected to a terminal, as airports such as those at Detroit, Tampa and Huntsville, Ala., offer.From Backstop To Better Product"In the 1960s and '70s, airport hotels were for distressed passengers" grounded by bad weather or a broken airplane, said Tyler Morse, chief executive of MCR Development, which is building a 505-room hotel in the former TWA Flight Center at JFK International Airport. JetBlue Airways (JBLU) is a minority owner of the project, which will be connected to the airline's Terminal 5. The hotel is planned to open in the third quarter of 2018. "They thought 'I should have this as a backstop. Let's do the bare-minimum kind of thing,'" Morse said. "And now people are saying, 'Hey, I can make money by having a higher-quality product.' "Stephen Joyce, chief executive of Choice Hotels International (CHH), said the deep airline capacity cuts of the 2000s led airports to retrench as business travel waned. Hotel developers then looked elsewhere, and much of the airport lodging stock aged. Today, the airport market is "becoming more interesting," Joyce said in a recent interview. "I bet we've got 10-12 projects in and around airports" that are under various stages of development.Mid- To High-End TravelersIn Minneapolis-St. Paul, Graves Hospitality is planning a $115 million hotel with a spa, rooftop suites, and as much as 40,000 square feet of meeting space. The 300-room property, attached to the airport's primary Terminal 1, will command rates that are 15% to 30% higher than local competing properties, at $225-$250 per night, said Benjamin Graves, president and chief executive."The primary business is corporations that are dealing with mid- to high-end travelers that fly in, go to a meeting; they don't have to get a taxi, they don't have to figure out the market and how to get different places," Graves said. Graves Hospitality is negotiating with a trio of major chains — Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide (HOT), Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT) and InterContinental Hotel Group (IHG) — about which will brand and operate the property, which is scheduled to open in January 2018."Go to any airport, and there's a zillion hotels within two miles," Morse said. "To really do this right, you've got to be physically connected."And at many airports, a day spa doesn't hurt either.

Investors are piling into U.S. hotels, hoping to cash in on stabilized occupancy and rising room rates amid a climate of cheap debt and depressed supply. It's a mix that has generated profits for the last three years and portends more of the same for the near future.

Through the end of May, hotel buyers and sellers had conducted $8.3 billion in transactions in the U.S., a year-over-year increase of $300 million, according to the Hotels & Hospitality Group of Chicago-based property broker Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL).
JLL also projects that lodging sales will reach $25 billion this year, a 13.6% increase over 2013.

The record-high stock market and rebounding home values have made consumers feel more confident and comfortable about taking vacations, said Arthur Adler, Americas CEO and managing director of JLL's hospitality group. On the business side, the modest economic recovery coupled with slow job growth has necessitated more travel for workers, he added.

More recently, group travelers have begun to book rooms with increasing frequency, which should give the industry a further boost, say Adler and Scott Smith, senior vice president in the Atlanta office of PKF Consulting USA, an advisory and real estate firm specializing in the hospitality industry.
Fundamental Rebound

The important group-bookings segment, which includes state organizations, business meeting groups and worker incentive travel programs, pulled back not only because of the slow recovery, but also as result of the negative reactions to the American International Group's (AIG) widely publicized retreat at a swanky resort soon after receiving bailout funds, Smith said.
Only now is the group travel segment beginning to book rooms on par with its activity before the recession, which should give the industry a further boost, he adds.

"I've been doing this for 25 years and have never seen the kind of economics that are driving hotel revenues right now," said Smith, referring to the steady rise in fundamentals and lagging construction of new rooms. "We think we're in a real sweet spot."

Investors think so, too. The R.W. Baird/STR Hotel Stock Index, which tracks the 15 largest publicly traded hotel companies, is up 11% year-to-date, outpacing the S&P 500 by about five percentage points.

Three of the six largest companies by market cap in IBD's Leisure-Lodging industry group are up by double-digit percentages this year: Marriott International 30%, Intercontinental Hotels Group (IHG) 24% and Hyatt Hotels (H) 23%.

Profits across all hotels rose an average of 10.1% in 2013, the third straight year of double-digit gains, according to PKF Consulting's research affiliate. It predicts that profits will increase more than 10% in 2014 and 2015 as average daily rates, occupancy and revenue per available room (RevPAR) — a gauge of hotel profitability — exceed pre-recession levels.

Hendersonville, Tenn.-based STR, a research firm covering the hotel industry, reported that the average daily rate finished the week of June 14 at $115.61, a year-over-year increase of 4.4%, and that average occupancy increased 2% to 71.6% over the same period in 2013. RevPAR ended the week at $82.82, on average, a 6.5% year-over-year hike.

Occupancy gains supported the bulk of income growth coming out of the recession, but now rising room rates are doing a more lucrative job, said Arthur Adler, Americas CEO and managing director of JLL's hotels and hospitality group.
"Even if you have no occupancy increase, to the extent hotels can increase their room rate, the more of that increase falls to the bottom line," he says.
Pipeline Growing

Experts downplay a rising construction pipeline — at least for the near term. More than 114,300 hotel rooms were under construction at the end of the first quarter, a year-over-year jump of 40%, according to Portsmouth, N.H.-based Lodging Econometrics.
Nearly 293,000 more rooms were in the pipeline, with some 161,700 of them slated to begin construction in the next 12 months, Lodging Econometrics said, although not all are likely to get built.

Developers are adding most rooms in the branded upper- and mid-scale select service segments, the firm reported, which include Marriott International's (MAR) Residence Inn, Hilton Worldwide Holdings' (HLT) Hilton Garden Inn and InterContinental Hotels Group's Holiday Inn Express.

Developers all but shut down new construction as occupancy and daily rates plummeted amid the recession. Historically the supply of new rooms typically grew 2% a year, said Lauro Ferroni, vice president, research and strategic advisory with JLL's hospitality group. But construction has fallen well short of that over the last few years — it was less than 1% in 2013, for example, and this year supply is expected to grow by 1%, he said.
For now, Smith thinks new supply will impact the market around 2018, which should translate into continued investment activity for the foreseeable future.

"Who knows what's going to really happen in 2018 — or tomorrow?" he asks. A drastic change in gas or airfare prices could affect hotel performance, he acknowledged, but the fact that room demand is outstripping supply has reduced investment risk when compared with previous cycles.
Private Equity Leads Way

Through May this year, private equity funds such as RockBridge Capital and KSL Capital Partners completed 33% of the hotel transactions, according to JLL. RLJ Lodging Trust (RLJ), Summit Hotel Properties (INN) and other real estate investment trusts conducted 21% of the deals.

Foreign buyers are also expressing more interest and are expected to plunk down $3 billion for hotels this year, Adler said. High-net-worth individuals and institutional investors such as life insurance companies and pension funds are pursuing lodging properties, too.
In mid-June, however, the Charlottesville, Va.-based financial research firm SNL Financial noted that REITs had shelled out $1.2 billion for hotels in 2014, a year-over-year decrease of 11%.

A slowdown in REIT acquisitions isn't unexpected, Adler said. The companies typically start buying at a downturn's end and then pull back later in the cycle as private equity funds that tap high amounts of debt plow into the market and push up prices.

During the Pebblebrook Hotel Trust's (PEB) first-quarter conference call in late April, for example, company CEO Jon Bortz noted that after pursuing a successful acquisition strategy early in the cycle, the company was happy to "cede" the market to highly leveraged buyers. Plus, he added, fewer quality assets were hitting the market.
The Bethesda, Md.-based owner of upscale hotels and resorts shelled out $376.3 million for 1,083 rooms in five properties over the last 18 months, according to SNL Financial data.

"We've gotten to the point where existing owners look out a couple of years and say, 'Wow, it looks pretty good, why should I be in a hurry to sell if I don't need to?'" Bortz said. "Even in our target markets, we think values are well above what we're willing to pay based on our three- to five-year outlook."Investors are piling into U.S. hotels, hoping to cash in on stabilized occupancy and rising room rates amid a climate of cheap debt and depressed supply. It's a mix that has generated profits for the last three years and portends more of the same for the near future.Through the end of May, hotel buyers and sellers had conducted $8.3 billion in transactions in the U.S., a year-over-year increase of $300 million, according to the Hotels & Hospitality Group of Chicago-based property broker Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL).JLL also projects that lodging sales will reach $25 billion this year, a 13.6% increase over 2013.The record-high stock market and rebounding home values have made consumers feel more confident and comfortable about taking vacations, said Arthur Adler, Americas CEO and managing director of JLL's hospitality group. On the business side, the modest economic recovery coupled with slow job growth has necessitated more travel for workers, he added.More recently, group travelers have begun to book rooms with increasing frequency, which should give the industry a further boost, say Adler and Scott Smith, senior vice president in the Atlanta office of PKF Consulting USA, an advisory and real estate firm specializing in the hospitality industry.Fundamental ReboundThe important group-bookings segment, which includes state organizations, business meeting groups and worker incentive travel programs, pulled back not only because of the slow recovery, but also as result of the negative reactions to the American International Group's (AIG) widely publicized retreat at a swanky resort soon after receiving bailout funds, Smith said.Only now is the group travel segment beginning to book rooms on par with its activity before the recession, which should give the industry a further boost, he adds."I've been doing this for 25 years and have never seen the kind of economics that are driving hotel revenues right now," said Smith, referring to the steady rise in fundamentals and lagging construction of new rooms. "We think we're in a real sweet spot."Investors think so, too. The R.W. Baird/STR Hotel Stock Index, which tracks the 15 largest publicly traded hotel companies, is up 11% year-to-date, outpacing the S&P 500 by about five percentage points.Three of the six largest companies by market cap in IBD's Leisure-Lodging industry group are up by double-digit percentages this year: Marriott International 30%, Intercontinental Hotels Group (IHG) 24% and Hyatt Hotels (H) 23%.Profits across all hotels rose an average of 10.1% in 2013, the third straight year of double-digit gains, according to PKF Consulting's research affiliate. It predicts that profits will increase more than 10% in 2014 and 2015 as average daily rates, occupancy and revenue per available room (RevPAR) — a gauge of hotel profitability — exceed pre-recession levels.Hendersonville, Tenn.-based STR, a research firm covering the hotel industry, reported that the average daily rate finished the week of June 14 at $115.61, a year-over-year increase of 4.4%, and that average occupancy increased 2% to 71.6% over the same period in 2013. RevPAR ended the week at $82.82, on average, a 6.5% year-over-year hike.Occupancy gains supported the bulk of income growth coming out of the recession, but now rising room rates are doing a more lucrative job, said Arthur Adler, Americas CEO and managing director of JLL's hotels and hospitality group."Even if you have no occupancy increase, to the extent hotels can increase their room rate, the more of that increase falls to the bottom line," he says.Pipeline GrowingExperts downplay a rising construction pipeline — at least for the near term. More than 114,300 hotel rooms were under construction at the end of the first quarter, a year-over-year jump of 40%, according to Portsmouth, N.H.-based Lodging Econometrics.Nearly 293,000 more rooms were in the pipeline, with some 161,700 of them slated to begin construction in the next 12 months, Lodging Econometrics said, although not all are likely to get built.Developers are adding most rooms in the branded upper- and mid-scale select service segments, the firm reported, which include Marriott International's (MAR) Residence Inn, Hilton Worldwide Holdings' (HLT) Hilton Garden Inn and InterContinental Hotels Group's Holiday Inn Express.Developers all but shut down new construction as occupancy and daily rates plummeted amid the recession. Historically the supply of new rooms typically grew 2% a year, said Lauro Ferroni, vice president, research and strategic advisory with JLL's hospitality group. But construction has fallen well short of that over the last few years — it was less than 1% in 2013, for example, and this year supply is expected to grow by 1%, he said.For now, Smith thinks new supply will impact the market around 2018, which should translate into continued investment activity for the foreseeable future."Who knows what's going to really happen in 2018 — or tomorrow?" he asks. A drastic change in gas or airfare prices could affect hotel performance, he acknowledged, but the fact that room demand is outstripping supply has reduced investment risk when compared with previous cycles.Private Equity Leads WayThrough May this year, private equity funds such as RockBridge Capital and KSL Capital Partners completed 33% of the hotel transactions, according to JLL. RLJ Lodging Trust (RLJ), Summit Hotel Properties (INN) and other real estate investment trusts conducted 21% of the deals.Foreign buyers are also expressing more interest and are expected to plunk down $3 billion for hotels this year, Adler said. High-net-worth individuals and institutional investors such as life insurance companies and pension funds are pursuing lodging properties, too.In mid-June, however, the Charlottesville, Va.-based financial research firm SNL Financial noted that REITs had shelled out $1.2 billion for hotels in 2014, a year-over-year decrease of 11%.A slowdown in REIT acquisitions isn't unexpected, Adler said. The companies typically start buying at a downturn's end and then pull back later in the cycle as private equity funds that tap high amounts of debt plow into the market and push up prices.During the Pebblebrook Hotel Trust's (PEB) first-quarter conference call in late April, for example, company CEO Jon Bortz noted that after pursuing a successful acquisition strategy early in the cycle, the company was happy to "cede" the market to highly leveraged buyers. Plus, he added, fewer quality assets were hitting the market.The Bethesda, Md.-based owner of upscale hotels and resorts shelled out $376.3 million for 1,083 rooms in five properties over the last 18 months, according to SNL Financial data."We've gotten to the point where existing owners look out a couple of years and say, 'Wow, it looks pretty good, why should I be in a hurry to sell if I don't need to?'" Bortz said. "Even in our target markets, we think values are well above what we're willing to pay based on our three- to five-year outlook."

Hilton Worldwide's (HLT) profit more than tripled in the first quarter on a 4.4% hike in revenue, topping estimates on both. The gain was fueled by rising business travel globally that lifted hotel use, pushing the company's stock price to a new high.
Hilton reported 13-cent earnings per share minus items, vs. 3 cents a year ago on $2.36 billion in revenue, up from $2.26 billion.
The world's largest hotel chain raised its full-year 2014 EPS guidance to 64 cents to 67 cents. Consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters was 60 cents a share.
The beat came amid a growth spurt for the hotel industry. The newly public company, which began trading in mid-December, opened 51 hotels with more than 9,000 rooms in the quarter.

"We remain No. 1 in rooms under construction in every major region of the world, with over an 18% share of all rooms under construction globally," CEO Christopher Nassetta said in a post-earnings statement.
The nearly 100-year-old company's portfolio of 10 brands includes 4,155 managed, franchised, owned and leased hotels and timeshare properties, with 686,790 rooms in 92 countries and territories.

Rival Marriott International (MAR) said on Tuesday that it plans to add 15 hotels globally to its Ritz-Carlton chain, in locales such as downtown Cairo and a beachfront in Bali, lifting the Ritz-Carlton hotel chain total to 100 hotels.

No. 3 Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), operator of the Sheraton, St. Regis, W Hotel, Westin and other branded hotels, earlier in the week said it signed an agreement to open a new Sheraton in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.
Hilton said that during Q1, systemwide comparable revenue per available room rose 6.6%, compared to a year ago.
Its room occupancy rate for the quarter was up 2 percentage points to 70% in the U.S. It was up a bit at 65% in Europe and fell slightly in its Middle East and Africa hotels to 62%.
Hilton shares gapped up 2.6% to 23.22 in five times the usual trading volume in Friday morning trading on the stock market.
Marriott was up fractionally, while Starwood Hotels eased less than 1%.

A scuba diver swims above a reef dotted with colorful fish. An elderly couple ballroom dances on a beach at sunset. A woman sits on the edge of a rock, meditating at twilight.Then "Diamond Resorts International (DRII): simplicity, choice, comfort," a voice says as the six-minute commercial on YouTube ends.Calling itself a provider of "affordable luxury and priceless memories," Diamond offers vacations in 34 countries at 93 managed resorts, 154 affiliated resorts, 52 affiliated hotels and four cruise itineraries.The vacation packages are low-priced — such as five days and four nights in Cabo San Lucas for $292 or four days and three nights in Las Vegas for $92 — and are a marketing tool.The catch is that customers must be creditworthy, age 25 and older, earning at least $50,000 annually and ready to watch a one-and-a-half to two-hour sales pitch for joining Diamond's club. In the club, members buy points to use toward vacation packages.One of the costliest getaways, a nine-day European cruise on Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings' (NCLH) Norwegian Star, costs 20,000 points at peak season. Among the cheapest, a one-week stay in an Ormond Beach, Fla., studio, runs 1,200 points in low season.Funding The FunDiamond plans to increase its sales force 5%-10% annually over the next few years and boost sales to Asian customers, CEO David Palmer told IBD. About 70% of customers finance their purchase at a 15% average annual interest rate. The rate varies by the down payment, which is typically 10%.Diamond bundles customers' loans into securities and resells them to insurance companies and other institutional investors, eliminating its risk in customer defaults. About 6% of customers default on their loans; about 3.5% default on maintenance fees, said Palmer.As a "Silver Elite" member, Lee Huffman of Anaheim Hills, Calif., pays a $2,400 annual maintenance fee and gets 15,000 points every year in perpetuity. The finance manager of a midsize bank in Southern California and his family have used the points to stay at Diamond Resorts in California, Cabo San Lucas, Paris and Sydney."We prefer the comfort, convenience and cost savings of timeshares over hotels even more now that we have a child," said Huffman. He views his timeshare as an asset in his estate that he can pass on to his 3-year-old son.As of Jan. 1, 2014, points start at $7.66 each with a minimum purchase of 2,500 points, for $19,150, according to DiamondResorts.com. Members must also pay annual maintenance fees, which vary based on their membership levels, and incidental assessment fees for renovations or large repairs.Huffman and 524,000 fellow Diamond members can be credited for fueling the company's rapid sales and earnings growth. In its third quarter as a public company, the Las Vegas-based firm exceeded analysts' expectations. It beat earnings and sales forecasts on top of lifting full-year guidance when it reported first-quarter results May 1.Revenue grew 18% year over year to $181 million, eclipsing the $177 million consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) vaulted 37% from a year ago to $67 million, topping JPMorgan's forecasts of $51 million by 31%.Diamond raised its full-year 2014 EBITDA guidance to $265 million to $280 million, from previous guidance of $255 million to $265 million, partly because it managed to refinance a 12% loan at a much lower interest rate. It expects to save it about $22 million a year in interest.Performance Since IPODiamond stock has risen 40% from its $14 IPO price in July 2013.In a conference call with analysts, CEO Palmer said the company uses a "capital-light model with minimal development capex required," which means that instead of building its own properties, Diamond adds inventory by buying out existing resorts. Diamond also collects fees from managing properties in homeowners associations."Unlike its peers, with no significant plans to invest capital in new timeshare development, it sources inventory from recapturing vacation ownership interests from members who default on payment of their homeowners association dues and its bank of unsold points," JPMorgan analyst Joseph Gregg and colleagues wrote in a note May 1.Inside The IndustryAbout 30% of Diamond's earnings come from managing resorts, a task that's very profitable, says Gregg."Diamond is in a position to generate appealing earnings growth, driven by what we view as sustainable operating momentum in vacation ownership and steady uplift in management fees," Gregg and colleagues noted. "We forecast improving free cash-flow performance, given growth in its higher-margin management business."Diamond is the 12th largest company by market cap in IBD's Leisure-Lodging industry group, whose biggest components are Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), Marriott International (MAR) and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT). The group is ranked No. 79 in performance of 197 that IBD tracks.Vacation ownership can be a controversial line of business, however, and Diamond is no stranger to complaints."In one year, fees rose by more than 40%. A similar figure the next year. Soon the maintenance fees exceeded the cost of staying in a Diamond Resorts apartment for a holiday through Expedia (EXPE), including airfares," a Gloucestershire, U.K.-based entrepreneur, who did not want his name published, said in an email. "To add insult to injury, it became almost impossible to get a booking for any property except during off peak."Diamond's management fees exceeded rental rates by 47% to 180% for various properties he saw online, he says, and when he refused to pay, he got calls every day — sometimes twice a day — and was told that he would be turned over to a collection agency. Diamond finally canceled his contract after he complained to every agency in the U.S. and U.K. that would listen, he says."I just made a right royal nuisance of myself," he said in an email.Unwanted Diamond points can be had for pennies on the dollar on eBay (EBAY) and timeshare-resale websites. Only 3% of timeshares sell on the resale market, says Jeff Griffen, a senior executive at ResortBailout.com. The East Hartford, Conn.-based firm helps clients unload a timeshare for one to three years in annual maintenance fees plus closing costs.Walking away from a timeshare is like letting a house go into foreclosure, which could result in property liens, stained credit histories and even wage garnishment, according to Griffen. In addition, customers can finance their purchase only through Diamond, he says.Over the past three years, 525 complaints against Diamond were filed with the Better Business Bureau. Owners in Koloa, Hawaii, filed a class-action lawsuit over a $65,822,529 water-intrusion assessment, local media reported.Investing RisksSince owning a timeshare is a luxury that most people can do without, a global or U.S. economic slowdown could deplete demand for new purchases or hinder people's ability to repay their loans."Currently, no effective secondary market exists to resell timeshare," Robert LaFleur and Whitney Stevenson, analysts at JMP Securities, wrote in a note May 2. "If an effective and cost-efficient secondary market develops, Diamond's ability to sell vacation interests through its existing sales channels could be seriously impaired."Among other risks, rising interest rates would increase borrowing costs for both Diamond and its customers, which could squeeze margins and dampen demand.Diamond will be increasingly more dependent on the securities market to get money and maintain growth in vacation-ownership sales, Gregg of JPMorgan says. Growth depends on its success in selling to new customers rather than existing customers.

Growth stocks show strength in a down market in many different ways.They can show tight weekly closes after a breakout, refusing to give up much ground.Or, when they do pull back, they show supporting action at their 10-week moving average.Another way great stocks show strength, either in a weakening market or in a bull market, is by forming a flat base.The price structure has been seen for decades in model-book studies of past stock market winners by IBD. Hilton (HLT) formed one in 1967 before a 232% advance in little more than a year. And Starbucks (SBUX) formed one in the second half of 2003 in the early stages of a new bull market. It more than doubled in 70 weeks.If you miss an initial breakout, watch for a potential flat base to form. It often appears after a stock breaks out of a cup with handle or a double bottom. In a flat base, the stock moves sideways in a tight price range for at least five weeks, showing a pullback of no more than 10% to 15%.Flat bases that show wide-and-loose, erratic swings should generally be avoided. Some might work, but plenty of others won't. If institutional support is truly strong for a stock, trading should be tight and orderly.The buy point in the flat base is 10 cents above the high of the left side of the base. A future Investor's Corner column will teach you how to identify earlier buy points in a flat base.Current Sector Leader Gilead Sciences (GILD) formed a flat base in 2012 that spawned a bullish upward move. It first cleared a consolidation in late July. The flat base that followed formed in five weeks and showed tight trading with a pullback of 9%.As the base formed, it paid a visit to its 10-week moving average (1).Gilead gapped out of the base at 35.25 (adjusted for a 2-for-1 split in early 2013) in the week ended Nov. 16, helped by news that a combination of its experimental hepatitis C therapies cleared the virus in all patients in a trial.Weekly volume in the breakout week totaled about 166 million shares (2), nearly double its average at the time.Buying a stock when it gaps out of a base is counterintuitive, but those who bought Gilead on the Nov. 12 breakaway gap up in price have been rewarded nicely. Gilead is up 163% from the 2012 breakout.

General Electric (GE) has unveiled Current, a subsidiary that integrates the industrial conglomerate's solar, energy-storage, electric-vehicle and light-emitting-diode businesses with its Predix platform. Several high-profile customers, such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), are early Current users.The Fairfield, Conn.-based company said Current will begin with more than $1 billion in revenue and will build on General Electric's experience with energy and technology. Several GE customers are piloting Current to cut costs and boost energy efficiency, GE said. Users include JPMorgan Chase, Hilton Worldwide (HLT), Hospital Corp. of America (HCA) and Walgreens (WBA).Current will be headquartered in the Boston area with an additional presence in Silicon Valley. Roughly 200 new jobs focused on software, energy project management and outcomes selling will be created, GE said. Operations are underway and will increase next year, GE said.General Electric shares rose 1.2% to 27.62 in the stock market today.The news comes as engineers from Tesla Motors (TSLA) and Microsoft (MSFT) are teaming up with colleagues from Columbia University and the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, to develop a "software-defined battery." This development purportedly would allow different batteries with different chemistries to be integrated into one system.If successful, the findings could revolutionize consumer battery technology and meet customer demands for longer battery life, quicker charging and diversified chemistry.Tesla has expanded into battery storage for residential, business and utility-scale applications.Tesla stock fell 3.9% to 231.96 — closing pennies above its 200-day line — amid continued concerns about the Model X price tag, while Microsoft shares rose 3 cents to 46.78.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

In the world of commercial real estate in America, the South is rising. Atlanta overtook San Francisco in sales volume in the first six months of the year as investors looked beyond the usual major metro markets to secondary markets, where yields can be higher.

With sales volume up 66% over the same time in 2014, to nearly $7.5 billion, Atlanta placed fifth in total volume, pushing San Francisco to No. 6, according to a mid-year report from Real Capital Analytics.Atlanta had been hit hard by the housing downturn and "far back in the pack" as recently as 2012. But concerns over the area's health "have faded," RCA noted.Manhattan retained its throne as No. 1 in volume, as sales jumped 60% to $26.5 billion. Los Angeles followed with $12.7 billion, Chicago with $10.8 billion and Dallas at $8.2 billion.Houston was No. 11 as deal volume jumped 29% to $6.3 billion, a "positive sign," said RCA, "given that some investors were worried about this market when energy prices began their tumble."Some of the fastest growing markets in terms of deal volume were in the South, including Orlando, West Palm Beach and Raleigh/Durham, with sales up 232%, 159% and 97%, respectively. Volume in the D.C./Virginia suburbs was up 99%, to $4.5 billion.Deal volume nationwide jumped 36% to $225.1 billion during the first six months of the year. But it was "front loaded" in the first quarter, which was up 49%, RCA noted. Sales in the second quarter totalled $118 billion, up 23%.Slower growth in Q2 might not be a bad thing, though, RCA noted. Global commercial real estate investment money is betting big on the U.S. this year. Global transactions in the U.S. jumped 30% in the second quarter, leading all other regions, according to JLL (JLL), a global real estate services firm.
The big bounce in U.S. transactions helped lift total volumes in the Americas 18%, vs. a year earlier, to $79 billion. It was the best second-quarter showing since 2007.

And it helped keep total worldwide volume in the second quarter about equal to the same period a year ago, at $161 billion, despite volatility in China's equity markets and the debt crisis in Greece, JLL said in a preliminary Q2 report released this week.

In contrast, transaction volume in the Asia-Pacific region fell 19% to $26 billion, pulled down by declines in Japan and Australia. Europe, the Middle East and Africa volumes dropped 10% to $56 billion, though in local currencies it was up 11%, JLL said.
China stepped up investments in the U.S. sharply this year, according to Brian Ward, president of capital markets and investment services at Colliers International (CIGI).
In the first six months of 2015, China invested about $5 billion in U.S. real estate, about $1 billion more than in all of 2014, he said in an email to IBD.
He says Colliers expects China investments in the U.S. to reach as much as $12 billion this year.
Where China Buys In The U.S.

Last year, he said, investment capital from China was focused mainly on New York, San Francisco, Boston, Los Angeles and Houston. But this year, Chinese commercial real estate investors "are expanding their markets to include Seattle, Chicago, Hawaii."
Colliers expects the flow of real estate investment out of Asia to jump more than 60% this year over last year's record $46 billion as investors seek geographical diversification and better returns.
Colliers expects the U.S. and Europe to absorb more than 70% of that flow.

But U.S.-based money also has been actively buying commercial properties in the U.S. According to Real Capital Analytics, some of the top commercial deals closed earlier this year involved a diverse group of buyers based in the U.S.
Among them wereSalesforce.com (CRM), LaSalle Hotel Properties (LHO) and Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), all for properties in San Francisco.

Other big buyers were Facebook (FB) in Menlo Park, Calif., AvalonBay Communities (AVB) in New York City, Chesapeake Lodging Trust (CHSP) in Miami Beach and Essex Property Trust (ESS) in Los Angeles.Global commercial real estate investment money is betting big on the U.S. this year. "Belong anywhere," Airbnb's catchy tagline, is now somewhat ironic, because some U.S. cities are enacting strict short-term rental laws and even outright bans on renting one's home to a vacationer.
New York and the California cities of San Francisco, Los Angeles and Santa Monica are among those that have either passed new rules or are working through the legal process to draft new restrictions.
What's a rental host to do, with good potential income at stake from selling short-term stays in a spare home — or even in your only home — when you're away?

Rental websites and rental property associations can help owners keep up with occupancy tax codes, safety regulations and more. But if the rules are in flux in your area, experts say, you need to seek advice from local government agencies.

"If you want to rent short-term, you're going to have to call City Hall and find out all the regulations," said Carl Shepherd, co-founder of vacation rental website HomeAway (AWAY), based in Austin, Texas.
Battle Lines
Shepherd is steeped in the shifting short-term-rental regulation landscape, but notes that it varies markedly from city to city.

He says that officials in Florida, Hawaii and other resort areas are "versed in how to do short term rentals (STRs)." They dictate management policies and collect occupancy taxes, which fill government coffers and can provide funding for tourism promotion.

Nonetheless, New York City banned short-term rentals with a law that went into effect in May 2011. And last month, Santa Monica approved strict new rules that require hosts to be onsite, get a business license, turn over detailed renter information and pay a 14% occupancy tax on all rentals under 30 days. The city says it will use those taxes to hire an enforcement staff.
L.A.'s current rules make most STRs illegal. Proposed changes would allow more, only if the rentals are an owner's main residence.

Meanwhile, San Francisco currently restricts short-term rentals to 90 days per year, but a committee wants to reduce that figure to 60 days. The city's Board of Supervisors postponed a scheduled June 9 vote on the measure until July 14. A push is also under way to get a short-term rental rules measure onto the local ballot for a November vote.
San Francisco's rules say that a host, who may or may not be the property owner, must live in the city for at least 270 days a year to rent a unit short-term. It bans STRs by absentee owners.
A state measure is expected to come up for consideration in the next legislative session that supports local governments' regulatory efforts.
Do bans and limitations work? Take New York City. "Everyone's listings have grown since the ban, TripAdvisor (TRIP), HomeAway, Airbnb and Craigslist," said Shepherd. "And nobody is collecting taxes."
He says that obviously these bans don't work, they just drive rentals "underground."

Many cities suffer from a shortage of affordable housing and have for decades. And some officials in San Francisco and Santa Monica say that short-term rentals are reducing the long-term-rental and affordable-housing stock.

But "STRs are such a small percentage of the whole housing stock" that banning them won't have a material impact on long-term rentals, said Robert St. Genis, director of operations at the Los Angeles Short Term Rental Alliance (LASTRA), a group working with short-term rental owners.

St. Genis says Santa Monica and L.A. should focus on the benefits of short-term rentals. According to research funded by LASTRA, in 2013 STR guests spent over $518 million in L.A. The study estimates that short-term rentals have created 12,000 new jobs in the city.
Cities should collect occupancy tax on short-term rentals, St. Genis says, and use them to fund affordable housing development instead of using the money to police rentals.

Are cities bowing to pressure by hotels and hospitality worker unions, which argue that short-term rentals harm their industry and threaten jobs? The short-term rental market has grown, with TripAdvisor, HomeAway, Airbnb and FlipKey competing with parts of the hotel industry and time-share offerings by Hilton (HLT), Marriott Vacations Worldwide (VAC) and others.
Santa Monica's Cara Brown, a property owner, believes city officials are listening to lobbying from the hotels. Brown and others say that short-term rentals offer an affordable alternative to hotels.

"When I look at hotel rates in some of the major U.S. cities, it's clear that a lot of people feel like those rates are more than they want to or could spend," said Stifel analyst Simon Yarmak, who follows the lodging industry. He says that hosts on Airbnb and HomeAway offer lower-cost rentals for students and travelers on tight budgets.

Brown owns a fourplex, with two long-term, rent-controlled units, another long-term rental and one "very small" unit that she was renting short term for extra income after her retirement. With the new rules, she's taking the short-term unit off the market.
She was renting it when she wasn't there, which is now illegal. Because of onerous rent-control rules she won't rent it long-term.
"I don't want someone to live there for the rest of my life," she said.
Information Resources

Brown says that property owners can turn to rental associations and publications for help on rules. And local property managers and real estate agents can be a resource on local tax laws and how to manage short-term rentals.
Also, HomeAway and other sites provide management tools that homeowners can use to streamline their rental paperwork.

For example, HomeAway has partnered with HotSpot Tax, which runs a website that facilitates the remittance of occupancy taxes on behalf of vacation rental owners. And HomeAway users can have taxes automatically added to each transaction.
Market experts say property owners will push back on rental bans and rules. "This is America; property rights matter," said Jan Freitag, senior vice president at hotel industry research firm STR.
Owners are organizing. LASTRA has a GoFundMe site that's raising money to lobby local officials. And HomeAway has been active in helping groups like LASTRA, said St. Genis.
Airbnb hasn't been so helpful, some say.
"Airbnb doesn't seem to want to play with others," said St. Genis. He said they didn't include his group in a recent rally, and he "was incredibly disappointed and amazed."
Airbnb officials declined repeated requests for an interview for this story. The company is rumored to be planning an IPO, possibly for this year.
Airbnb, however, is part of the Short Term Rental Advocacy Center along with HomeAway, TripAdvisor and FlipKey. The center helps communities "engage with policymakers" on short-term rental rules.
Freitag says that ultimately cities will be more pragmatic.

"Money talks and if there's an income stream to NYC and other cities (via short-term rental occupancy taxes), then they'll try to get their hands on it," he said."Belong anywhere," Airbnb's catchy tagline, is now somewhat ironic, because some U.S. cities are enacting strict short-term rental laws and even outright bans on renting one's home to a vacationer.New York and the California cities of San Francisco, Los Angeles and Santa Monica are among those that have either passed new rules or are working through the legal process to draft new restrictions.What's a rental host to do, with good potential income at stake from selling short-term stays in a spare home — or even in your only home — when you're away?Rental websites and rental property associations can help owners keep up with occupancy tax codes, safety regulations and more. The economic recovery since the 2007-09 recession has been lackluster. Despite stock market gains, the mood of business is cautious. If this truly is a recovery in the economy, and not just the stock market, where's the joy? For most businesses, the joy is missing.
Yet, there's one area where industry insiders sound joyful — the hotel industry. In fact, compared to most executives, the lodging insiders sound wildly confident.
On Wednesday, the day before the annual NYU International Hospitality Industry Investment Conference, HotelNewsNow.com reported quotes from industry insiders like this:

"We are busier than we have been in ages," one said. Another said, "The one word I have heard a lot is frothy." A third pointed to "tremendous liquidity." A fourth asked, "What could possibly go wrong?"
Yet, for all the confidence, two things are clear. One is negative and the other positive.

On the negative side, IBD's Leisure-Lodging stock group has only matched the Nasdaq this year — up 7%. In the past three months, the lodging group fell 3% vs. a 2% gain for the Nasdaq in the stock market.
A selective approach doesn't fare much better. The four stocks with the best EPS Ratings in the lodging group also have slumped.
Marriott International (MAR) is down 5% over the past three months and up only 1% year to date.
Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) is off 7% over three months and flat so far this year.
Hilton Worldwide (HLT) is up 1% over three months but up 12% year to date.
Starwood Hotels and Resorts (HOT) is up 4% over three months and 4% so far this year.
Why the disconnect between the stocks and the business?

A monthly chart of the lodging stock group shows that, from a broader perspective, there is no disconnect. Lodging stocks are up 157% since they began their run in October 2011, outperforming the Nasdaq's 110% gain and the S&P 500's 86% gain in the same period.
The monthly chart for lodging stocks shows there have been several periods of consolidations during the run. The consolidations generally lasted four to six months before another spurt up.
Currently, the lodging group is shaping the fourth month of a consolidation.
On a more positive note, declines in the four hotel stocks mentioned above have been modest this year.
Marriott's pullbacks in the past six months have not exceeded 9%. The stock is sketching an early stage, 9% deep flat base now. The same can be said of Hilton, which is in a flat base.
Wyndham's pullbacks haven't gone beyond 11%, but Starwood has shown sloppy and somewhat deeper pullbacks.
With the stock market choppy and tough to play, stocks that avoid deep dives are easier to hold.

So individual investors might want to put the better lodging stocks on a watch list.The economic recovery since the 2007-09 recession has been lackluster. Forecasts for an improving economy and low gas prices should result in a busy summer for the U.S. tourism industry and a bullish outlook for companies that make money on free-spending vacationers.One of the likely beneficiaries is Marriott Vacations Worldwide (VAC). It develops, markets, sells and manages vacation ownership and related products — aka timeshares — under the Marriott Vacation Club, Grand Residences by Marriott and Ritz-Carlton Destination Club brands.Although Marriott Vacations Worldwide isn't as tied to macro factors as other travel-related stocks such as airlines, hotel operators and cruise lines, it still gets a lift when times are good."The numbers in terms of people driving, as well as the forecasts for air travel, are back to pre-2008-09 levels. That bodes well for us," Chief Financial Officer John Geller told IBD. "Going into the summer, we are optimistic and the trends are good."Reflecting that optimism, Marriott Vacations Worldwide stock hit a record high of 89.85 on May 28 and is up about 18% this year.It is one of a number of stocks in IBD's Leisure-Services group to hit new highs in recent weeks. The group ranks No. 35 of 197 industries tracked and has moved steadily higher over the past six months.Other leaders in the group are a diverse mix that includes cruise operator Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH), sports and entertainment company Madison Square Garden (MSG) and fellow timeshare company Interval Leisure Group (IILG).The Price Of ParadiseMarriott Vacations, which was spun off from Marriott International (MAR) in November 2011, has 59 resorts worldwide. In coming quarters, it will open new resorts in San Diego, Miami Beach and Hawaii.The company competes with the vacation ownership divisions of hotel rivals such as Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) and Hyatt Hotels (H).Marriott Vacations Worldwide plays in the high end of the market. The company's average first-time buyer spends $30,000 to $35,000 for the ability to stay a week each year — perpetually — at a two-bedroom, two-bath vacation home in locations such as Orlando, Fla., and Hilton Head, S.C.That compares with an average sales price of about $20,000 industrywide, according to data from the American Resort Development Association (ARDA), a timeshare trade association.It sounds like a lot of money until you start doing the math, says ARDA CEO Howard Nusbaum."It's not like real estate in the sense that you don't make money flipping it," he told IBD. "Your value comes from your use of the property. If you spend $3,000 a year for vacations, in 10 years you spent $30,000."With a timeshare, you might spend that much and get a lifetime's worth of vacations, Nusbaum says.About half of Marriott Vacation Worldwide's revenue comes from contract sales to customers. It gets about 20% from resort management and other income, including what comes from some ancillary businesses like food and beverage, spas and golf courses, in addition to management fees.Another 20% comes from renting out unsold units. The remaining 10% comes from providing financing to customers, most of whom can't get timeshare loans from traditional lenders.For most of its three-plus years as a standalone company, Marriott Vacation Worldwide's revenue growth has hovered in the single digits. That's primarily because it spent its early years focusing on operating efficiently rather than growing rapidly."Coming out of the spin-off, our focus was really about improving margins and looking at how to operate as a standalone company," CFO Geller said. "We were less concerned about driving top-line growth."From Crisis To CruisingMeanwhile, the timeshare industry itself was still emerging from the beating that it took in 2008-09, when the recession and financial crisis made it all but impossible for many Americans to get timeshare loans.Normally, the industry isn't that vulnerable to economic swings. That's because travelers who own timeshares don't have to worry about coming up with money for a place to stay. But the downturn of 2008-09 was different because "the financing dried up overnight," Nusbaum said. Industry revenue fell by nearly half."Timeshare companies couldn't get loans, so they couldn't offer loans to customers," he said. "We had 20 years of double-digit growth, but the 2008-09 downturn was very humbling."With those problems behind the industry, it is now back to double-digit growth, he says.As for Marriott Vacations Worldwide, it has moved into a new phase where it can put more focus on top-line growth. During the first quarter, it posted a 13% year-over-year revenue increase — its biggest gain since going public."In the first quarter, we started to ramp up our marketing efforts," Geller said. "We shifted our focus more to first-time buyers."First-time buyers account for only about 40% of the company's contract sales, he says. The rest comes from sales to existing owners looking to upgrade or add to their portfolios."We want to get that to more of a 50/50 ratio," Geller said.In the first quarter, Marriott Vacations Worldwide posted total revenue of $454.9 million, up from $401.9 million a year earlier. Total company contract sales climbed 23% to $198.4 million, while earnings rose 52% to 85 cents a share, as calculated on a diluted basis, topping the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Renting 'Experiences' Pays OffMarriott Vacations Worldwide describes its points system, which members use to choose resorts and "pay" for stays, as a "flexible 'vacation currency.'"And the company has added not only resorts but also things like cruises, guided tours and "experiences" that range from ski trips to golf excursions."As we have been able to put our Destination Club in place — and it's really gotten a lot of traction — keep in mind that when our owners decide that they want to use their Vacation Club points for something other than staying in one of our resorts, whether they want to take a cruise or they want to take a tour or go to the Masters or whatever, they give us back those points for the year," CEO Steve Weisz said on the company's Q1 conference call in May. "We turn around and take them into the open market, and we rent them. So that drives the revenue side of things."If it all works right," Weisz said, "we actually make a little bit in the arbitrage between what we rent it for and what we have to pay for the cost to fulfill the particular thing that they asked for, whether it be the cruise or the trip."Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company's full-year EPS to rise 19% in 2015 and another 16% in 2016."As the economy improves and wealth improves, demand for people going on vacation increases both in terms of the duration of their breaks, the number of breaks, and how much they're spending on different amenities like timeshares," MKM Partners analyst Christopher Agnew told IBD. "That should be good for the industry."

Hyatt Hotels Corp. (H) saw its shares move about 2% higher in the stock market today after the giant hotel chain's first-ever investor meeting Friday, and as analysts see an improved environment for hotel business in general.

"Hotel stocks bounced back in February as emerging market fears subsided and investors focused on earnings reports and companies' 2014 outlooks," said David Loeb, hotel analyst at Robert W. Baird & Co., in a research note Friday. "Despite the inclement weather year to date that has had a negative impact on performance, hotel fundamentals remain sound and there is favorable momentum heading into the seasonally stronger spring quarter, which has investors optimistic and hotel stocks at or near cycle highs."
The Baird/STR Hotel Stock Index reported a 5.5% increase from January to February, according to a report Friday from Baird.

Meanwhile, IBD's Leisure-Lodging industry group, ranked No. 111 of 197, is up 4% since the end of January. And Hyatt, whose profits surged by at least 28% in each of the past four quarters, has seen its stock rise 7% so far this year.
IBD's leisure-lodging industry group also includes Marriott International (MAR) and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT).
Stifel analyst Simon Yarmak outlined some of the highlights from Hyatt's meeting in a research note.
"Over the last 10 years, management has made great strides repositioning the company," he wrote.

The steps, he said, included consolidating the company under one umbrella, maintaining a strong balance sheet, expanding into select service brands, creating a franchising platform, going public (which brought in outside shareholders) and appointing Mark Hoplamazian as CEO.

The company has also make "significant strides," Yarmak added, since its IPO in the fourth quarter of 2009. Over the last four years, adjusted EBITDA has grown at a 14.0% CAGR, he notes, with owned and leased operating margins improving by 600 basis points to 24.0%.

Hyatt also has "industry-leading systemwide growth, and it has the largest relative pipeline," he said. This cycle, he noted, hotels in the system increased 31.0% to 523, with rooms growing 21.0% to 145,324. Hyatt has opened hotels in over 72 new markets. And 40% of its hotels are in the top 25 markets worldwide. The company opened 51 hotels, or 10.1% growth, last year. An additional 40 hotels are expected to open in 2014.
Yarmak notes another positive is that Hyatt's room count has grown in all three of its regions.
Owning real estate has its advantages, he adds, noting that Hyatt has some of the highest exposure to owned and leased EBITDA (59.0%).
"The company's owned hotels provide operating leverage. Owning hotels makes the company a better manager and provides capital when sold," he said.

Hyatt's outlook is bright, in Yarmak's view: "Over the next three to five years, Hyatt will have a higher-quality owned portfolio with strong operating performance, sector-leading relative systemwide growth in key markets, and will have the ability to return $1.2 billion of cash to shareholders," he noted.
Last year, the IPO market saw the debut of major hotel chains Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT) in December and Extended Stay America (STAY) in November.

"The arrival of Hilton and Extended Stay as publicly traded companies is yet another indicator of the strong position hotel companies have among investors," Randy Smith, co-founder and chairman of STR, said in a prior research note.

Commercial real estate firm JLL noted earlier this year that the hospitality industry is on strong footing, with fundamentals "driven by growing business and leisure travel in major gateway markets, as well as in secondary markets and resort destinations throughout the Americas."Hyatt Hotels Corp. President Obama was in Panama on Friday, set to meet with leaders from around the Americas, including Cuban President Raul Castro. In December, Obama and Castro announced efforts to reduce tension and increase trade and travel between their countries.
Cuba is one of four nations listed by the State Department as a sponsor of terrorism, a designation that carries automatic economic sanctions.
That might change, since the easing of restrictions would introduce a new emerging economy to the world stage.

Citigroup (C) on Thursday said it was evaluating a return to Cuba, but that progress would take time, according to Reuters. Bloomberg reported in January that Marriott International (MAR) and Hilton Worldwide (HLT) were expressing interest in the country.
But near-term possibilities for investors appear limited.

The Herzfeld Caribbean Basin Fund (CUBA) is the most obvious way to place a bet on Cuba. Its holdings include companies with possibly some of the strongest exposure to the country among publicly traded issues. That isn't necessarily saying a lot.
The fund's largest holding is Panama-based airline Copa Holdings (CPA). Copa operates a small portion of its business in and out of airports in Havana and Santa Clara.
The stock has been pounded largely by the drop in travel to and from Venezuela. Copa is up 3% for the year, but 32% below its July high.
Also at the top of the list are engineering firm MasTec (MTZ) and fruit-grower Fresh Del Monte Produce (FDP), both based in Florida.

Mastec builds communications and utilities infrastructure, was found  ed and is managed by a Cuban family, and has some entree to the economy there. But the Miami Herald in December quoted Mastec Chairman Jorge Mas as saying the company would not consider doing business in Cuba in the near future due to an uncertain and unfriendly business environment.
Travel seems the avenue likely to see the clearest near-term improvement, and the Herzog fund reported a new position in Spirit Airlines (SAVE) to seize on that possibility.

But U.S. and Cuban regulators must sit down and hash out and agree on travel rules before any airlines can initiate flights.President Obama was in Panama on Friday, set to meet with leaders from around the Americas, including Cuban President Raul Castro. Despite beating third-quarter earnings expectations, shares of Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) sank after its full-year 2015 outlook fell short of analyst projections.
The hotel and vacation rental company earned $1.67 a share in Q3, an 18.4% jump from last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting $1.63.
Revenue increased 6.1% to $1.514 billion, missing analyst views by $15 million.

Wyndham upped its full-year 2014 EPS outlook to a range of $4.45 to $4.48, from $4.34 to $4.44, with the new midpoint about 4 cents above analyst views. That doesn't include any adjustment due to share repurchases, which the board just expanded.
Wyndham reiterated its estimate for 2014 revenue, at $5.25 billion to $5.35 billion, with the midpoint roughly in line with the consensus.

But for 2015, Wyndham said it sees EPS in the range of $4.70 to $4.85 on revenue in the range of $5.4 billion to $5.5 billion. That's below the consensus, which had projected EPS of $4.96 on revenue of $5.635 billion.
By midafternoon trading, shares had fallen 2.5% to 76.43 in the stock market today.

For the third quarter, Wyndham's vacation ownership segment accounted for about 46% of revenue, which rose 4% to $704 million. The rise primarily reflects 8% higher net vacation ownership interest revenues, which benefited from a lower loan loss provision, the company said.

The vacation exchange and rentals segment, which generated about 34% of Wyndham's Q3 revenue, climbed 9% to $512 million. Excluding the impact of acquisitions and currency changes, revenue was up 6% in the segment. Exchange revenues rose 3% to $162 million and vacation rental revenues jumped 13% to $331 million.

Revenue from the lodging segment, which accounted for 20% of revenue in Q3, rose 6% to $315 million. Wyndham said the increase primarily reflects higher revenue per available room (RevPAR) and increased fees related to the company's co-branded credit card program.
Domestic RevPAR increased 8.4%, but international RevPAR declined 3.5% due to growth in lower RevPAR countries and unfavorable currency effects, Wyndham said.

The number of rooms within the company's hotel system increased 2.7% from last year to 655,300 in 7,590 properties. By Sept. 30, Wyndham had more than 950 hotels and in excess of 116,000 rooms in development, 57% overseas.

Wyndham repurchased 2 million shares in Q3 for $161 million. From Oct. 1-23, it repurchased an additional 600,000 shares for $50 million. Wyndham said its board approved an additional $1 billion in share repurchases, bringing the remaining repurchase authorization total to $1.1 billion.
The Leisure-Lodging group ranks No. 40 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks. Top stocks typically come out of the top quartile of IBD's groups.
Wyndham holds the No. 1 spot within the group, with a 94 Composite Rating, meaning its shares outperform 94% of all stocks on the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors.
Hyatt Hotels (H) and Hilton Worldwide (HLT) both have a 91 Composite Rating, while Marriott International (MAR) has an 82 CR.

Marriott International (MAR) will be the first of a trio of top hotel companies to announce third-quarter earnings this week in a different economic climate than last quarter.

Reports indicate hotels outperformed the market last quarter, but the spread of Ebola to New York City and other locales in the U.S. could dampen enthusiasm for domestic travel this quarter. The companies may be asked in earnings calls whether they expect an Ebola impact.
Marriott is slated to announce Q3 earnings Tuesday after the market closes. Hyatt Hotels (H) will report on Wednesday morning, and Hilton Worldwide (HLT) is slated for Friday before the market opens.

The reports will provide a better picture of how hotels fared in the quarter after Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) last Friday beat Q3 expectations but sank nearly 3% after its full-year 2015 forecast fell short of analyst estimates. Wyndham shares fell 0.1% to 76.27 in Monday trading in the stock market today.

Consensus of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for Marriott's earnings to rise 19% to 62 cents per share, up from 52 cents in Q3 2013. Marriott topped estimates the prior two quarters. Revenue is projected to climb 20.4% to $3.43 billion.
The Bethesda, Md.-based company has said it plans to invest $2.5 billion to $2.7 billion from 2014 to 2017, primarily to develop new hotels and add rooms to existing ones.

Rising business and leisure travel is sparking a strong recovery in the hotel industry as room demand outstrips increased supply, and investors are showing interest in hotel stocks.According to commercial real estate firm Marcus & Millichap, the U.S. hotel sector will reach new highs in occupied rooms and room revenue this year, with occupancy rates exceeding pre-recession levels."The expanding economy and strengthening job market will spark additional spending by businesses and consumers, helping to fill more hotel rooms," Marcus & Millichap said in a quarterly research report this week.Hotel stocks have been faring well in this environment. IBD's Leisure-Lodging industry group, ranked No. 26 of 197 groups, has risen 12% vs. the S&P 500 index's 8% for the year to date. This month Marriott International (MAR) is up 3% and Hyatt Hotels (H) 2%. They and other major hotel operators Hilton Worldwide (HLT), Intercontinental Hotels (IHG) and Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) are all up between 10% and 44% year-to-date.Marcus & Millichap's analysis of hotel industry demand predicated that the national occupancy rate would climb to 63.4% from 62.2% last year and that average daily rates would rise 4.5% to $115.31. Higher room rates and increased demand will lead revenue per room to grow 6.5% this year and overall revenue 7.5%, it said. In the first six months of the year, the nationwide average daily room rate rose 4.1%, slightly more than the rise a year ago. Revenue per average room jumped 7.5%, topping last year's 5.6% gain.The report noted that new brands and "refreshes" by hotels reflect the industry's "courting of the millennials," those born between the 1980s to early 2000s. The huge new boom generation will likely account for nearly half of business-flight spending by 2020, the report added.Among the new brands and refreshes are Hilton's new Curio concept, consisting of independent hotels under the Hilton banner, and AC Hotels being introduced by Marriott in Miami, Chicago, New Orleans and New York, with more to come.Demand for hotel rooms was strongest in Denver, Nashville, Atlanta, San Diego and Dallas, according to Marcus & Millichap. Room demand in Denver jumped 10.7% in the first six month of 2014. A late recovering economy in Atlanta lifted room demand there.Among IBD's highest-ranked hotel stocks by Composite Rating are Wyndham, with a 97 out of a possible 99, Hyatt at 94, and then Marriott and Hilton at 93 and 92, respectively.
